xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels
Class AbstractKernelDensityEstimator

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.functions.AbstractFunction<java.lang.Number,java.lang.Double>
      xxl.core.math.functions.AbstractRealFunctionFunction
          xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels.AbstractKernelDensityEstimator
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, Function<java.lang.Number,java.lang.Double>, RealFunction
Direct Known Subclasses:
HybridKernelDensityEstimator, NativeKernelDensityEstimator, ReflectionKernelDensityEstimator
public abstract class AbstractKernelDensityEstimator
extends AbstractRealFunctionFunction

One main problem of nonparametric statistics is the estimation of the probability density function (pdf) of a random variable. The estimation typically relies on a given sample, in our case data given by objects of type Number. For density estimation kernel based techniques are quite robust and useful. There, for each data point X_i a kernel is centered at X_i. Then, the sum is built over all kernels. The kernel density estimator inherits the basic properties of the kernel function. For this function different choices are possible whereas a pdf is advisable (that is restricted to [-1,1] in our case). The mostly used kernels are positive and symmetric with a compact support, e.g., the Epanechnikow kernel or the Gaussian kernel. The choice of the bandwidth h, which controls the degree of smoothness, is crucial for the quality of the estimation. There is a trade-off in choosing the bandwidth. If h is too high, the resulting estimate is smooth and may hide local features of the density. For a small bandwidth, the estimate will be spiky and artificial artifacts may be introduced.
The estimator itself extends AbstractRealFunctionFunction. Thus, it is implemented as a one-dimensional function expecting objects of type Number as well as a RealFunction expecting data of type double.
The estimator is updatable, so one can use it as an aggregate function combined with a special aggregation iterator. Since this class provides a preimplementation it is abstract and implementing classes only need to implement the method evalKDE(double x). Note: A sample of any kind of data given by an iterator could be easily obtained through the reservoir sampler cursor.
Generally, a more detailed coverage of kernel based density estimation respectively cdf estimation is given in [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. 1992.

See Also:
Aggregator, Function, KernelFunction, KernelBandwidths, AbstractRealFunctionFunction, NativeKernelDensityEstimator, ReflectionKernelDensityEstimator, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

AbstractKernelDensityEstimator

public AbstractKernelDensityEstimator(KernelFunction kf,
                                      java.lang.Object[] sample,
                                      double h,
                                      double alpha)
Gives a skeleton implementation for a kernel based density estimation function.

Parameters:
kf - used Kernel function.
sample - sample of a data set given as Object[] containing objects of type Number.
h - used bandwidth for computing the estimation
alpha - confidence level used for computing an asymptotic pointwise confidence interval

AbstractKernelDensityEstimator

public AbstractKernelDensityEstimator(KernelFunction kf,
                                      java.lang.Object[] sample,
                                      double h)
Gives a skeleton implementation for a kernel based density estimation function. The thumb rule respectively normal scale rule is used for computing the bandwidth.

Parameters:
kf - used Kernel function.
sample - sample of a data set given as Object[] containing objects of type Number.
h - used bandwidth for computing the estimation

epsilon

public double[] epsilon()
                 throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the current confidence interval for the last computed function point.
This method computes a pointwise confidence interval for the kernel density estimator. For further details see
[Hae91]: W. Haerdle, Smoothing Techniques, With Implementations in S, Springer, New York, 1991, p. 62.

Returns:
current epsilon of the confidence interval given by [ f(x)-epsilon_low, f(x)+epsilon_up]
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if no confidence level alpha has been given and hence no confidence interval for the given value can be computed

epsilon

public double[] epsilon(double x)
                 throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the current confidence interval for given value x.
This method computes a pointwise confidence interval for the kernel density estimator. For further details see [Hae91]: W. Haerdle, Smoothing Techniques, With Implementations in S, Springer, New Yor, 1991, p. 62.

Parameters:
x - argument where to evaluate the confidence interval
Returns:
current epsilon of the confidence interval given by [ f(x)-epsilon, f(x)+epsilon]
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if no confidence level alpha has been given and hence no confidence interval for the given value could be computed

Returns p=1-alpha.
